{{coord|51.7009|-2.8220|name=St Jerome, Llangwm Uchaf}}}} |[[File:St.Jerome's, Llangwm.jpg|100px|alt=A stone church in a graveyard behind evergreen trees]] |align="center"|{{sort|1150|12th century}} |The church has 12th century origins and was restored in 1863–1878. Its features include a formidable tower to the north side, an elaborately carved early 15th century screen, 19th century floor tiles and the 19th century east window.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/llangwm-uchaf/ |title=Llangwm Uchaf |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|1|I}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=2028 |title= Church of St Jerome, Llangwm Uchaf |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Cynhaearn's Church, Ynyscynhaearn|St Cynhaearn]] |{{sort|Gwynedd, Ystumllyn|[[Ystumllyn]], [[Gwynedd]]
{{coord|52.9262|-4.1945|name=St Cynhaearn, Ystumllyn}}}} |[[File:Eglwys Cynhaearn, Ynyscynhaearn - geograph.org.uk - 1818524.jpg|70px|centre|alt=A simple church, seen end-on, with a bellcote and transepts; in the foreground are gravestones]] |align="center"|{{sort|1150|12th century}} |The church stands in an isolated position on what used to be an island in a former lake, and is approached by an ancient [[causeway]]. Its structure dates from the 12th, 16th and 17th centuries, while most of the interior fittings are [[Georgian architecture|Georgian]] in style, dating from 1832.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/ynyscynhaearn/ |title=Ynyscynhaearn St Cynhaearn |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|2|II*}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=4291 |title= Church of St. Cynhaearn, Ystumllyn |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Mary's Church, Tal-y-llyn|St Mary, Tal-y-llyn]] |{{sort|Anglesey, Aberffraw|Near [[Aberffraw]], [[Anglesey]]
{{coord|53.2277|-4.4484|name=St Mary, Tal-y-llyn}}}} |[[File:St. Mary's, Tal-y-llyn, Anglesey. - geograph.org.uk - 105399.jpg|100px|alt=A stone very simple church see from the west end. The only features are a small round-headed door, a small bellcote, and a tiny rectangular window]] |align="center"|{{sort|1155|12th century (probable)}} |This is a simple [[Middle Ages|medieval]] church that is virtually unrestored. Its fabric dates from the 12th century (probably) and the 16th and 17th centuries. Most of the furnishings are from the 18th century, although some have had to be replaced because of vandalism in the 20th century.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/tal-y-llyn/ |title=Tal-y-Llyn St Mary |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|1|I}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=5275|title= Chapel of St. Mary (Tal-y-llyn) and churchyard walls |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Mary's Church, Derwen|St Mary]] |{{sort|Denbighshire, Derwen|[[Derwen]], [[Denbighshire]]
{{coord|53.0455|-3.3882|name=St Mary, Derwen}}}} |[[File:St Mary's Church, Derwen - geograph.org.uk - 733298.jpg|100px|alt=A small stone church with a slate roof see from the southwest. Scaffolding surrounds the west end and bellcote, and the porch]] |align="center"|{{sort|1250|13th century}} |St Mary's Church retains late pre-[[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]] stone carving, and a [[rood screen]] with its loft. Its fabric dates from the 13th century, and it was restored in 1857. The churchyard contains a pre-[[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]] cross and a sundial, both of which are listed.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/derwen/ |title=Derwen St Mary |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}}{{Citation | last =Hubbard | first =Edward | authorlink = Edward Hubbard| coauthors = | title =The Buildings of Wales: Clwyd |edition= | publisher =[[Penguin Books|Penguin]] | year = 1986| location =London | pages = 155–156 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn =0-14-071052-3 }} !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|1|I}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=725 |title= St. Mary's Church, Derwen |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Odoceus' Church, Llandawke|St Odoceus]] |{{sort|Carmarthenshire, Llandawke|[[Llandawke]], [[Carmarthenshire]]
{{coord|51.7732|-4.4904|name=St Odoceus, Llandawke}}}} |[[File:Llandawke Church - geograph.org.uk - 68422.jpg|100px|alt=A stone church with a slate roof seen from the southwest. Nearest is a relatively large tower with a pyramidal roof, beyond which is body of the church]] |align="center"|{{sort|1250|13th century}} |Having been built in the 13th century, it was remodelled during the following century, and restored in the [[Victorian era]]. When it was taken over by the charity in 2006 it was in "a state of dereliction"; repair and restoration work has been carried out.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/llandawke/ |title=Llandawke |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade II colour}}|{{sort|3|II}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=9683 |title= St. Odoceus' Church, Llandawke|publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Ellyw's Church, Llanelieu|St Ellyw]] |{{sort|Powys, Llanelieu|[[Llanelieu]], [[Powys]]
{{coord|52.0000|-3.1887|name=St Ellyw, Llanelieu}}}} |[[File:St Ellyw's Church Llanelieu - geograph.org.uk - 61685.jpg|100px|alt=A simple single-storey church seen from a distance with a bellcote and a porch; sheep graze in front of it]] |align="center"|{{sort|1250|13th century}} |In an isolated position in the [[Brecon Beacons]], it has retained much of its [[Middle Ages|medieval]] interior, including wall paintings and a [[rood screen]]. It is used as a venue for the annual [[Talgarth Festival]].{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/llanelieu/ |title=Llanelieu St Ellyw |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|1|I}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=6622 |title= Church of St Ellywe, Llanelieu|publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Michael and All Angels Church, Llanfihangel Rogiet|St Michael and All Angels]] |{{sort|Monmouthshire, Llanfihangel Rogiet|[[Rogiet#Llanfihangel Rogiet|Llanfihangel Rogiet]], [[Monmouthshire]]
{{coord|51.5850|-2.7857|name=St Michael, Llanfihangel Rogiet}}}} |[[File:Llanfihangel Rogiet, St Michael's Church - geograph.org.uk - 69770.jpg|100px|alt=A stone church seen from the south, with a square battlemented tower at the left, then the nave, and a lower chancel at the right. In front of the church is the base of a medieval cross]] |align="center"|{{sort|1250|13th century}} |The church stands close to a group of farm buildings. Following a programme of restoration work by the charity, it is managed by the Local History Society.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/llanfihangel-rogiet/ |title=Llanfihangel Rogiet |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|2|II*}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=2035 |title= Church of St Michael and All Angels, Llanfihangel Rogiet |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Brothen's Church, Llanfrothen|St Brothen]] |{{sort|Gwynedd, Llanfrothen|[[Llanfrothen]], [[Gwynedd]]
{{coord|52.9503|-4.0521|name=St Brothen, Llanfrothen}}}} |[[File:St Brothen 0005.jpg|100px|center]] |align="center"|{{sort|1250|13th century}} |The church was re-roofed in the 15th century, additions were made in the 17th century, and restorations took place in the 19th century. It retains its [[rood screen]] constructed from the wood of trees felled between 1496 and 1506.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/llanfrothen/ |title=Llanfrothen St Brothen |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|1|I}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=4804 |title= St. Brothen's Church, Llanfrothen|publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[Hodgeston Parish Church]] |{{sort|Pembrokeshire, Hodgeston|[[Hodgeston]], [[Pembrokeshire]]
{{coord|51.6585|-4.8503|name=Hodgeston Parish Church}}}} |[[File:Hodgeston Church - geograph.org.uk - 218148.jpg|100px|alt=A simple church seen from the southeast with a tall slender tower on the left, then the nave and a chancel with a slightly higher roof line]] |align="center"|{{sort|1255|13th century (probable)}} |At the beginning of the 19th century the church was "in extreme disrepair". It was renovated in the 1850s, but retained many of its internal features, including a [[Norman architecture|Norman]] [[baptismal font|font]], a double [[piscina]], and a triple [[sedilia]].{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/hodgeston/ |title=Hodgeston |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|2|II*}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=5959 |title= Hodgeston Parish Church |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Decumanus's Church, Rhoscrowther|St Decumanus]] |{{sort|Pembrokeshire, Rhoscrowther|[[Rhoscrowther]], [[Pembrokeshire]]
{{coord|51.6794|-5.0332|name=Rhoscrowther Church}}}} |[[File:St Decuman's, Rhoscrowther - geograph.org.uk - 1338416.jpg|100px|alt=A church with a tall church tower positioned centrally.]] |align="center"|{{sort|1250|13th century (possibly)}} |Mainly medieval church with a tall tower, dedicated to [[Decuman|St Decumanus]] (St Decuman). Has four side chapels associated with houses in the parish. Located beside a large oil refinery. {{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/rhoscrowther/ |title=Rhoscrowther St Decumanus |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|1|I}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=174283 |title=Church of St Decumanus |accessdate=20 December 2016 |publisher=CADW}} |- |[[Manordeifi Old Church]] |{{sort|Pembrokeshire, Manordeifi|[[Manordeifi]], [[Pembrokeshire]]
{{coord|52.0584|-4.5855|name=Manordeifi Old Church}}}} |[[File:Manordeifi Old Church.jpg|100px|alt=A stone church seen from an angle in a graveyard, with a porch and a bellcote]] |align="center"|{{sort|1300|13th or 14th century}} |The church stands close to the [[River Teifi]]. Following repairs in the earlier part of the 19th century, it was abandoned as a [[parish church]] in 1899, and taken into the care of the charity in 2002. The tradition of keeping a [[coracle]] in the porch in case of flooding continues to be maintained.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/manordeifi/ |title=Manordeifi Old Church |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|2|II*}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=15115 |title= Manordeifi Old Church |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Baglan's Church, Llanfaglan|St Baglan]] |{{sort|Gwynedd, Llanfaglan|[[Llanfaglan]], [[Gwynedd]]
{{coord|53.1210|-4.3095|name=St Baglan, Llanfaglan}}}} |[[File:St Baglans Church 08.JPG|100px|alt=At the far end of a graveyard is a simple stone church, which appears L-shaped, and has a bellcote]] |align="center"|{{sort|1350|14th century}} |St Baglan's stands in an isolated position in a field. It escaped restoration in the 19th century, and retains its 18th-century furnishings, including communion rails, [[pulpit]] with [[sounding board]], [[box pew]]s and benches.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/llanfaglan/ |title=Llanfaglan St Baglan |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|1|I}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=18619 |work= Historic Wales |title= St. Baglan's Church, Llanfaglan|publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Beuno's Church, Penmorfa|St Beuno]] |{{sort|Gwynedd, Penmorfa|[[Penmorfa]], [[Gwynedd]]
{{coord|52.9402|-4.1721|name=St Beuno, Penmorfa}}}} |[[File:St Beuno's Church, Penmorfa.jpeg|100px|alt=The north side of stone church with a slate roof, seen through a graveyard. There are two windows, a protruding vestry and, at the right, a bellcote]] |align="center"|{{sort|1350|14th century}} |The [[chancel]] was added in the 15th century, and the [[vestry]] and porch in the 18th century. During the 19th century there were three restorations, but it retains its [[Middle Ages|medieval]] roof.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/penmorfa/ |title=Penmorfa St Beuno |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|2|II*}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=4623 |title= Church of St Beuno, Penmorfa |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[Llanfair Kilgeddin#Church of St. Mary the Virgin|St Mary]] |{{sort|Monmouthshire, Llanfair Kilgeddin|[[Llanfair Kilgeddin]], [[Monmouthshire]]
{{coord|51.7731|-2.9349|name=St Mary, Llanfair Kilgeddin}}}} |[[File:St. Mary's church, Llanfair Kilgeddin - geograph.org.uk - 1688848.jpg|100px|alt=A stone church seen from the southwest, with a slate roof and red tiled ridge. At the west end is a door a window and a double bellcote; protruding from the south side is a porch]] |align="center"|{{sort|1360|Mid to late 14th century (possible)}} |Although it was rebuilt in 1875–76, the church retains [[Middle Ages|medieval]] contents, including a [[baptismal font|font]]. The walls are decorated in [[Arts and Crafts Movement|Arts and Crafts]] style [[sgraffito]] with designs by [[Heywood Sumner]] based on the ''[[Benedicite]]''.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/llanfair-kilgeddin/ |title=Llanfair Kilgeddin St Mary |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|1|I}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=2782 |title= Church of St Mary the Virgin, Llanfair Kilgeddin |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[Old Church of St Afran, St Ieuan and St Sannan, Llantrisant|St Afran, St Ieuan and St Sannan]] |{{sort|Anglesey, Llantrisant|[[Llantrisant, Anglesey|Llantrisant]], [[Anglesey]]
{{coord|53.3277|-4.4798|name=St Afran, St Ieuan and St Sannan, Llantrisant}}}} |[[File:Llantrisant Old Church - geograph.org.uk - 1358390.jpg|100px|alt=A T-shaped low stone church with a slate roof seen beyond grave slabs]] |align="center"|{{sort|1375|Late 14th century}} |Sited in an isolated position by a farm, it became redundant in 1899 when a new church was built nearer the centre of the settlement. By 1970 it was in ruins and without a roof. It was repaired in 1976–77 and came into the care of the charity in 2002.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/llantrisant/ |title=Llantrisant SSS Afran, Ieuan & Sannan |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|2|II*}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=5314 |title= Church of St Afran, St Ieuan and St Sannan |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Mary's Church, Penllech|St Mary]] |{{sort|Gwynedd, Penllech|[[Penllech]], [[Gwynedd]]
{{coord|52.8775|-4.6466|name=St Mary, Penllech}}}} |[[File:Eglwys Santes Fair Penllech - geograph.org.uk - 557200.jpg|100px|alt=A simple stone church seen almost from the east end. The east window has two lights and a slightly pointed arch, and at the far end the bellcote can be seen]] |align="center"|{{sort|1450|15th century (probable)}} |The church stands on an old [[pilgrim]]s' route. Although it was substantially rebuilt in 1840, its interior retains its [[Georgian architecture|Georgian]] style. Since coming under the care of the charity in 2009, repairs have been undertaken.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/penllech/ |title=Penllech St Mary |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|2|II*}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=4380 |title= Church of St Mary, Penllech |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St David's Church, Llangeview|St David]] |{{sort|Monmouthshire, Llangeview|[[Llangeview]], [[Monmouthshire]]
{{coord|51.7017|-2.8742|name=St David, Llangeview}}}} |[[File:Llangeview Church - geograph.org.uk - 252069.jpg|100px|alt=A small stone church seen from an angle; behind the chancel is a slightly higher nave with a bellcote at the far end. A porch protrudes beyond that]] |align="center"|{{sort|1475|Late 15th century}} |The interior of the church is largely unrestored and contains a 15th-century [[rood screen]] with its loft, and rare pre-Victorian [[box pew]]s and other fittings. It was declared redundant in 1999, and repairs to the exterior have been carried out.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/llangeview/ |title=Llangeview St David's |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|1|I}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=2711 |title= Church of St David, Llangeview |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Figael's Church, Llanfigael|St Figael]] |{{sort|Anglesey, Llanfigael|[[Llanfigael]], [[Anglesey]]
{{coord|53.3158|-4.5114|name=Llanfigael Church}}}} |[[File:Eglwys Figel Sant - geograph.org.uk - 157667.jpg|100px|alt=A small plain stone church seen from an angle with a bellcote on the near gable, and a simple door and two windows along the side]] |align="center"|{{sort|1750|18th century (probable)}} |The church was largely rebuilt in 1841 and has retained most of its 19th-century interior. It also contains three [[baptismal font|fonts]], the oldest dating back to the 12th century. Since taking it over, the charity has re-roofed it and reintroduced timber [[tracery]] in the windows.{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/llanfigael/ |title=Llanfigael |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade II colour}}|{{sort|3|II}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=5296 |title= Church of St Figael |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Andrew's Church, Bayvil|St Andrew]] |{{sort|Pembrokeshire, Bayvil|[[Bayvil]], [[Pembrokeshire]]
{{coord|52.0314|-4.7688|name=St Andrew, Bayvil}}}} |[[File:Bayvil church - geograph.org.uk - 391061.jpg|100px|alt=A simple stone church seen from the south. The only visible features are a west bellcote and two windows]] |align="center"|{{sort|1825|Early 19th century}} |This is thought to be an early 19th-century rebuild of a [[Middle Ages|medieval]] church, and it has been unaltered since. Its features include [[box pew]]s, a three-decker [[pulpit]] with a [[sounding board]], and a 12th-century [[baptismal font|font]].{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/bayvil/ |title=Bayvil St Andrew |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|2|II*}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=12756 |title= Church of St Andrew, Bayvil |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Michael's Church, Tremain|St Michael's Church]] |{{sort|Ceredigion, Tremain|Tremain, [[Ceredigion]]
{{coord|52.1078|-4.5782|name=St Michael, Tremain}}}} |[[File:St. Michael Church - geograph.org.uk - 54226.jpg|70px|centre]] |align="center"|1846–48 |John Jones, otherwise known by his [[bardic name]] of [[Talhaiarn]], designed the church in [[English Gothic architecture#Early English Gothic|Early English]] style. Jones is acknowledged as the first Welsh architect to have been trained formally, and this is the only building he designed exclusively by himself.{{Citation | last = | first = | author-link = | publication-date = January 2012| date = | year = | title = A New Vesting| periodical = Newsletter| series = | publication-place = | place = | publisher = Ancient Monuments Society and Friends of Friendless Churches| volume = | issue = | pages = 5–6| url = | issn = | pmid = | pmc = | doi = | oclc = | accessdate =}} !{{Grade II* colour}}|{{sort|2|II*}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=15871|title= Church of St Michael, Tremain|publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Mark's Church, Brithdir|St Mark]] |{{sort|Gwynedd, Brithdir|[[Brithdir, Gwynedd|Brithdir]], [[Gwynedd]]
{{coord|52.7487|-3.8332|name=St Mark, Brithdir}}}} |[[File:St Mark's Church - geograph.org.uk - 212038.jpg|100px|alt=Part of a stone church with a large slate roof seen from a slight angle; on the left is a slightly protruding porch with wooden gates, and on the summit is a bellcote]] |align="center"|1895–98 |Designed by [[Henry Wilson (architect and designer)|Henry Wilson]], this is considered to be one of the finest [[Arts and Crafts Movement|Arts and Crafts]] churches in Wales. It was commissioned in memory of Rev [[Charles Tooth]], founder of [[St Mark's English Church, Florence]].{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/brithdir/ |title=Brithdir St Mark's |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade I colour}}|{{sort|1|I}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=16008 |title= Church of St Mark, Brithdir|publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |- |[[St Teilo's Church, Llandeloy|St Teilo]] |{{sort|Pembrokeshire, Llandeloy|[[Llandeloy]], [[Pembrokeshire]]
{{coord|51.8975|-5.1162|name=St Teilo, Llandeloy}}}} |[[File:St Eloi's Church, Llandeloy - geograph.org.uk - 896771.jpg|100px|alt=A simple stone church with a slate roof, a bellcote on the nearest gable and a transept on the right]] |align="center"|1926 |The church was built from [[Middle Ages|medieval]] ruins and designed by [[John Coates Carter]] based on the principles of the [[Arts and Crafts Movement]]. Its interior is dominated by a carved [[rood screen]] and a painted [[reredos]].{{Citation |url=http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/llandeloy/ |title=Llandeloy St Eloi |accessdate=12 November 2016 |publisher=Friends of Friendless Churches}} !{{Grade II colour}}|{{sort|3|II}}{{Citation |url= http://cadwpublic-api.azurewebsites.net/reports/listedbuilding/FullReport?lang=en&id=14397 |title= Church of St Teilo, Llandeloy |publisher=[[Cadw]] | accessdate= 20 December 2016}} |} ==See also== * [[Churches Conservation Trust]] – the trust for redundant Church of England churches in England * [[Historic Chapels Trust]] – the trust for redundant non-Anglican places of worship in England {{geogroup}} ==Notes== {{note label|Location|A|A}}The distinctive characteristic of voluntary sources is that the donor receives nothing in return for the money given. It includes grants from government and other charitable sources, as well as public gifts, donations and legacies.{{Citation | url = http://www.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/ShowCharity_Help_Page.aspx?ContentType=Chart_Help_Income&SelectedLanguage=English | title = The Register of Charities — Notes for Users | accessdate = 2 August 2010| publisher = [[Charity Commission]]}}
{{note label|Location|B|B}}This is the date of first construction of the existing building. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://friendsoffriendlesschurches.org.uk/}} * {{Citation |last=Saunders |first=Matthew |year=2007 |title=Fifty Years of the Friends of Friendless Churches |series=Historic Churches |publisher=Cathedral Communications |url=http://www.buildingconservation.com/articles/fiftyyears/fiftyyears.htm |accessdate=7 August 2010 |ref=none}} * {{Citation |last=Saunders |first=Matthew |date=March 2006 |title=Protecting the disused but beautiful |volume=93 |publisher=Institute of Historic Building Conservation |url=http://www.ihbc.org.uk/context_archive/93/saunders/church.html |accessdate=7 August 2010 |ref=none}} {{Churches Conservation Trust}} {{featured list}} [[Category:Charities based in London]] [[Category:Heritage organisations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Conservation in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Lists of churches in England]] [[Category:Lists of churches in Wales]] [[Category:Architectural history]] [[Category:Churches preserved by the Friends of Friendless Churches|*]] [[Category:1957 establishments in the United Kingdom]]

The '''Golden LEAF Biomanufacturing Training and Education Center (BTEC)''' is a multidisciplinary instructional center at [[North Carolina State University]] that provides education and training to develop skilled professionals for the [[biomanufacturing]] industry. Biomanufacturing refers to the use of living organisms or other biological material to produce commercially viable products. Examples include therapeutic proteins, [[monoclonal antibodies]], and [[vaccine]]s for medical use; amino acids and enzymes for food manufacturing; and biofuels and biochemicals for industrial applications. BTEC provides hands-on education and training in bioprocessing concepts and biomanufacturing methods that comply with [[Good manufacturing practice|cGMP]] (current Good Manufacturing Practice), a set regulations published by the United States [[Food and Drug Administration|Food and Drug Administration (FDA)]].
BTEC reports administratively through the university's [[North Carolina State University College of Engineering|College of Engineering]] and is guided by an advisory board made up of representatives from the biomanufacturing industry and other organizations interested in biotechnology and biomanufacturing.
In 2003, North Carolina's [[Golden LEAF Foundation]] provided almost $39 million to build BTEC, as part of a larger grant to establish a statewide public-private partnership now called [[NCBioImpact]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncbiotech.org/sites/default/files/03AnnualReport.pdf |title=2003 Annual Report for the North Carolina Biotechnology Center |publisher=ncbiotech.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://wraltechwire.com/business/tech_wire/biotech/story/2732340/|title=WRALtechwire article |publisher=wraltechwire.com}}</ref> The state of North Carolina provided funds for process equipment and supports the operation of the facility. The NCBioImpact partnership now includes BTEC, BRITE (Biomanufacturing Research Institute and Technology Enterprise) at [[North Carolina Central University]], North Carolina BioNetwork of the [[North Carolina Community College System]], NCBIO (North Carolina Biosciences Organization), the [[North Carolina Biotechnology Center]], and the Golden LEAF Foundation. It was created to provide workforce training and development for the biotechnology industry, thereby fostering the growth of this economic sector in the state. According to the North Carolina Biotechnology Center, North Carolina is home to 528 biotechnology companies that provide 57,000 jobs and $1.92 billion in taxes for state and local government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncbiotech.org/business-commercialization/ |title=Cultivating a Rich Biotech Landscape |publisher=ncbiotech.org |date= |accessdate=2011-10-11}}</ref> Employment in the industry has grown 4.1% from 2008 to 2010, when other industries shed thousands of jobs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncbioimpact.org/economic-development.html |title=Economic Development |publisher=ncbioimpact.org |date= |accessdate=2011-10-11}}</ref> In recent years some of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies, e.g. [[Novartis]] and [[Merck & Co]], have located and/or expanded manufacturing operations in North Carolina.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncbiotech.org/business-commercialization/biotech-sectors/vaccines/inside-vaccines/novartis/ |title=Novartis Plans to Produce Vaccines by 2011 |publisher=ncbiotech.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncbiotech.org/article/merck-expansion-adds-vaccine-core/ |title=Merck Expansion Adds to Vaccine Core |publisher=ncbiotech.org}}</ref>
[[File:BTEC Facility_exterior.jpg|thumb|alt=Photo of exterior of BTEC facility.|BTEC Facility]]
==Facilities and equipment== BTEC opened in fall 2007 and was the first facility dedicated to biomanufacturing training.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncbiotech.org/sites/default/files/07AnnualReport.pdf |title=2007 Annual Report for the North Carolina Biotechnology Center |publisher=ncbiotech.org}}</ref> BTEC is 82,500 gross square feet and contains 63,000-gross square feet of laboratories, which range from small or bench scale to large-scale suites that simulate a biomanufacturing pilot plant capable of producing [[biopharmaceutical]] products. Upstream processes utilize bacteria, yeast, animal cells, and insect cells. Equipment in these spaces includes the following:
* Bioreactors, glass and stainless steel (2L - 300L) and disposable (10L - 250L) * Automation systems with distributed control architecture * Downstream recovery and purification equipment, and * Analytical instrumentation [[File:BTEC Bioreactors.jpg|thumb|alt=Photo of BTEC's 30L and 300L bioreactor.|Bioreactors in BTEC's Simulated GMP Lab]] The main BTEC facility is home to the North Carolina Community College System's BioNetwork Capstone Center, which operates an aseptic processing/filling suite and several bench-scale labs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncbionetwork.org/educational-resources/instructional-videos/bionetwork-capstone-center|title=Capstone Center |publisher=ncbionetwork.org}}</ref> In 2012, BTEC completed construction of additional laboratories in a nearby facility for cell culture, purification, and processing of active virus.
==University programs== BTEC delivers undergraduate and graduate courses to North Carolina State University students. Academic programs include the following:
* undergraduate certificate * undergraduate minor * post-baccalaureate certificate * graduate minor * a master's program offering two [[Professional Science Master's Degree|Professional Science Master's degrees]], a Master of Science in Biomanufacturing (MS) and a Master of Biomanufacturing (MR)
Curriculum was created with extensive input from industry professionals, and most courses include substantial hands-on laboratory work. Most BTEC courses are offered in a half-semester (eight-week) format, which enables students to complete a series of courses in one academic year.
==Job training== BTEC collaborates with industry partners to design, develop and deliver courses that provide professionals working for biomanufacturing companies, equipment vendors, or regulatory agencies with continuing education opportunities. Open-enrollment courses are offered throughout the year and are available to all interested parties. BTEC also regularly delivers courses customized to meet a client's specific needs for training.
BTEC provides biomanufacturing training specified in contracts of grants to provide training for government agencies. In 2007, the [[Food and Drug Administration|FDA]] awarded BTEC a 5-year contract to develop and deliver biomanufacturing training for FDA inspectors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncbioscience.org/news_and_events/newsletters/nov07/ncbio_nov07.htm |title=NCBIO Newsletter November 2007 |publisher=ncbioscience.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402121058/http://www.ncbioscience.org/news_and_events/newsletters/nov07/ncbio_nov07.htm |archivedate=2012-04-02 |df= }}</ref> In 2010, BTEC received a grant for almost $900,000 from [[Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority]] (BARDA), part of the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20100930007040/en/BARDA-Grants-Build-Global-Flu-Vaccine-Manufacturing |title=BARDA grants help build global flu vaccine manufacturing capacity |publisher=www.businesswire.com}}</ref> With funding from this grant, a team of instructors from BTEC, [[Duke University]], and industry provide a three-week course on influenza vaccine manufacturing. Trainees were selected by institutions participating in a U.S. government-sponsored program to build vaccine production capacity among countries with developing economies. Countries represented included Egypt, India, Indonesia, Mexico, Romania, Serbia, Russia, South Korea, Thailand, and Vietnam.
==Bioprocess and analytical services== When laboratories are not being used for training, BTEC uses them to perform a variety of services for scientists from industry, government, and academia. Projects involve technology development, process improvement/scale-up, analytical testing, and preparation of material for preclinical studies. These services allow scientists to advance their research projects toward commercialization. In turn, these advancements stimulate the North Carolina economy.
==Location== BTEC is located on the [[North Carolina State University Centennial Campus|Centennial Campus]] of [[North Carolina State University]] in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]], United States. The campus is approximately 15 miles east of [[Research Triangle Park]] and [[Raleigh-Durham International Airport]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.btec.ncsu.edu/ Golden LEAF Biomanufacturing Training and Education Center (BTEC)] * [http://brite.nccu.edu/ Biomanufacturing Research Institute and Technology Enterprise (BRITE)] * [http://www.centennial.ncsu.edu/ Centennial Campus] * [http://www.engr.ncsu.edu/ College of Engineering at North Carolina State University] * [http://www.goldenleaf.org/ Golden LEAF Foundation] * [http://www.merck.com/ Merck] * [http://www.ncbioimpact.org/ NCBioImpact] * [http://www.ncbionetwork.org/ North Carolina BioNetwork] * [http://ncbioscience.net/ North Carolina Biosciences Organization (NCBIO)] * [http://www.ncbiotech.org/ North Carolina Biotechnology Center] * [http://www.ncsu.edu/ North Carolina State University] * [http://www.novartis.com/ Novartis]

{{Infobox connector |name=HDBaseT |type=Consumer electronic networking cable |image= |logo=[[File:HDBaseT logo.svg|267px]] |caption=HDBaseT Alliance logo |designer=HDBaseT Alliance |design_date=June 2010 |manufacturer= |production_date= |superseded= |superseded_by= |superseded_by_date= |external= |hotplug=Yes |daisy_chain=Yes |length={{convert|100|m|ft}}, including the support of multi hops (8 x 100 m) |width= |height= |electrical= charging power up to 100 W<ref name="Technology Comparison Table">{{cite web|url=http://www.hdbaset.org/files/HDBaseT_Comparison_Table_Nereus.pdf|title=Technology Comparison Table|publisher=HDBaseT.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704200519/http://www.hdbaset.org/files/HDBaseT_Comparison_Table_Nereus.pdf|archivedate=2010-07-04|df=}}</ref> |ground= |maximum_voltage= |maximum_current= |audio_signal=Yes |video_signal=Yes, supports TV and PC video formats including standard, enhanced, high-definition, ultra high-definition (4k), and 3D video. |data_signal = Yes, also with [[Fast Ethernet]] (100 Mbit/s) |data_bit_width= |data_bandwidth = 10.2 Gbit/s<ref name="Technology Comparison Table"/> |data_devices= |data_style= |cable = [[Cat5e]] / [[Cat6]] |physical_connector = [[8P8C]] }}
'''HDBaseT''', promoted and advanced by the '''HDBaseT Alliance''', is a [[consumer electronic]] (CE) and commercial connectivity standard for transmission of uncompressed [[high-definition video]] (HD), audio, power, [[home network]]ing, Ethernet, USB, and some control signals, over a common [[category cable]] ([[Cat5e]] or above) using the same [[8P8C modular connector]]s used by [[Ethernet]].<ref name="Alliance">{{cite web |url= http://www.hdbaset.org |title= HDBaseT Alliance |work= Web site |publisher= HDBaseT.org}}</ref>
== History == The HDBaseT Alliance, incorporated on June 14, 2010 by [[Samsung Electronics]], [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]], [[LG Electronics]] and [[Valens (company)|Valens]], was developed to promote the HDBaseT standard originally created by Valens.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hd.engadget.com/2008/12/15/valens-hdbaset-tech-carries-hd-video-audio-and-internet-over-et/ |title=Valens HDBaseT tech carries HD video, audio and internet over Ethernet |website=Engadget |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120228192808/http://hd.engadget.com/2008/12/15/valens-hdbaset-tech-carries-hd-video-audio-and-internet-over-et/ |archive-date=2012-02-28}}</ref> The HDBaseT 1.0 specification was also finalized in June 2010.<ref>[http://www.fiercewireless.com/press-releases/hdbaset-alliance-announces-incorporation-finalized-specification/ HDBaseT Alliance Announces Incorporation, Finalized Specification]. Fierce Wireless, June 29, 2010</ref> External accessories, such as [[dongles]], were on the market in 2010 for devices not yet embedded with HDBaseT.<ref>[http://www.valens-semi.com/media/3152/display%20standard%20-%20interview%20about%20the%20alliance%20-%20march%202010.pdf Interview with Micha Risling from the HDBaseT Alliance] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717183945/http://www.valens-semi.com/media/3152/display%20standard%20-%20interview%20about%20the%20alliance%20-%20march%202010.pdf# |date=2011-07-17 }}. Display Standard, March 2010</ref> Products were demonstrated at the 2013 [[Consumer Electronics Show]].<ref>{{Cite news |title= HDBaseT Alliance Shows the Future of Connected Home Entertainment at CES 2013 |date= January 9, 2013 |work= News release |url= http://www.hdbaset.org/files/Static%20Page%20Files/HDBaseT%20Alliance%20Evolution%20news%20release_FINAL.pdf |accessdate= June 5, 2013 }}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In mid-2013, the HDBaseT Alliance issued Spec 2.0, an update to the original specification, which enriches the HDBaseT offering to the pro-AV market, and enables a multimedia home connectivity solution. Spec 2.0 specifies the HDBaseT network protocol, defining the required adaptations across all layers of the [[OSI model]], to provide the optimized services for time sensitive applications, such as high throughput video and audio. Spec 2.0 maintains all the features of Spec 1.0, but also adds networking, switching, and control-point capabilities such as flexible and fully utilized mesh topology, distributed routing, and end-to-end error handling, enabling multipoint-to-multipoint connectivity and multistreaming. Spec 2.0 also embeds USB 2.0, enabling touch-screen functionality and keyboard-video-mouse (KVM) for no-latency transmission of ultra-high-definition audio and video. It also specifies either category cable or fiber as the transmission medium.
The [[IEEE]] has announced that HDBaseT has been accepted as the '''IEEE 1911''' standard.<ref>{{citation |url=http://standards.ieee.org/news/2015/HDBaseT.html |title=IEEE to Adopt the HDBaseT Standard for Ultra-High-Definition Digital Connectivity |date=6 January 2015}}</ref>
An [[Internet Protocol]] (IP) version of HDBaseT was demonstrated in 2017.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ul5-wStrK9U&feature=youtu.be&t=2m8s |title=Valens @ ISE 2017 presenting HDBaseT over IP |date=Feb 16, 2017}}</ref><!--Kvng RTH-->
== Features == HDBaseT is transmitted over [[Category 5 cable|category 5e]] cables or above up to 100 m (328 ft) long, with [[8P8C modular connector]]s of the type commonly used for [[Ethernet]] [[local area network]] connections.<ref>[http://www.avrev.com/home-theater-news/industry-trade-news/samsung-lg-sony-and-valens-form-the-hdbaset-alliance.html Samsung, LG, Sony and Valens form HDBaseT Alliance]. Audio Video Revolution, December 17, 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.valens-semi.com/media/1593/valens_5playpaper_final%20v1.1.pdf 5Play Convergence and the Next HD Digital Connectivity Standard-White Paper] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717183543/http://www.valens-semi.com/media/1593/valens_5playpaper_final%20v1.1.pdf |date=2011-07-17 }}. Valens Semiconductor, accessed March 23, 2010</ref>
HDBaseT transmits uncompressed ultra-high-definition video (up to 4K), audio, power over HDBaseT (PoH - up to 100W), Ethernet, USB, and a series of controls such as RS232 and IR.
HDBaseT is complementary to standards such as [[HDMI]], and it is an alternative to [[radio frequency]], [[coaxial cable]], [[composite video]], [[S-Video]], [[SCART]], [[component video]], [[D-Terminal]], or [[VGA]]. HDBaseT connects and networks CE devices such as [[set-top boxes]] except Cisco and Scientific Atlantic boxes, [[DVD]] players, [[Blu-ray Disc]] players, [[personal computers]] (PCs), [[video game consoles]], switches, matrices, projectors, and [[AV receivers]] to compatible [[digital audio]] devices, [[computer monitors]], and digital televisions.<ref>[http://hd.engadget.com/2008/12/15/valens-hdbaset-tech-carries-hd-video-audio-and-internet-over-et/ Valens HDBaseT tech carries HD video, audio and internet over Ethernet] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704223242/http://hd.engadget.com/2008/12/15/valens-hdbaset-tech-carries-hd-video-audio-and-internet-over-et# |date=2010-07-04 }}. HD.Engadget.com, December 15, 2009</ref><ref>[http://hd.engadget.com/2008/12/15/valens-hdbaset-tech-carries-hd-video-audio-and-internet-over-et/ Valens-HDBaseT up the ante on AV wiring] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704223242/http://hd.engadget.com/2008/12/15/valens-hdbaset-tech-carries-hd-video-audio-and-internet-over-et# |date=2010-07-04 }}. Entertainment Technology Center, January 8, 2010</ref>
=== Video===
HDBaseT delivers [[uncompressed video|uncompressed ultra-HD video]] (up to 4K) to a network of devices or as a point-to-point connection. Uncompressed content supports all video sources, including legacy products, accurately renders gaming graphics and features such as [[electronic program guides]], and does not degrade video quality or add latency. It supports [[TV]] and [[Personal Computer|PC]] video formats, including standard, enhanced, high-definition, ultra-HD (4K), and 3D video.<ref name="HDBaseT Technology: A Better HDMI Extender">{{cite web|url=http://www.cepro.com/article/inside_hdbaset_technology_a_better_hdmi_extender/|title=HDBaseT Technology: A Better HDMI Extender|publisher=CE Pro|accessdate=2010-07-19}}</ref> Due to bitrate limitations of 10.2 Gbit/s instead of the required 18 Gbit/s in the HDMI 2.0 specification, HDBaseT 2.0 can only support uncompressed 4K at 30 Hz with 4:4:4 color coding, or 4K at 60 Hz with 4:2:0 color coding, but not the full 60 Hz with 4:4:4 color.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cepro.com/article/handling_4k_distribution_using_hdbaset_2_0#|title=Handling 4K Distribution Using HDBaseT 2.0|first=Jason|last=Knott|website=www.cepro.com}}</ref>. However, using either very light visually-lossless compression or color space conversion (CSC), it is possible to pass 4K/60/4:4:4 formats over an HDBaseT 2.0 link. The visually-lossless compression also provides support for HDR10 formats.{{cn|reason=Can we have some details? Is this theoretical or has it been demonstrated or delivered?|date=January 2018}}
===Audio===
Audio is a requirement for most consumer electronics devices. Audio is passed through the same media as video, so all standard formats are included.<ref name="HDBaseT Technology: A Better HDMI Extender"/> HDBaseT does not support the [[Audio Return Channel#ARC|Audio Return Channel (ARC)]], a feature found on [[Hdmi#Version 1.4|HDMI 1.4]].
=== Ethernet===
HDBaseT supports the [[Fast Ethernet|100 Mbit/s]] version of [[Ethernet over twisted pair]]. This can provide [[Internet access]], or enable televisions, stereos, computers and other CE devices to communicate with each other and access multimedia content, including video, pictures and music stored on the local network.<ref name="HDBaseT Technology: A Better HDMI Extender"/>
===Power over HDBaseT===
Sending power over the same LAN cable gives the option to forgo plugging devices into the wall for power. HDBaseT uses a variation of [[Power over Ethernet]] (PoE) standard called "power over HDBaseT" to provide up to 100W of power to CE devices, such as Blu-ray players, monitors and TVs, and eliminate the need for external power cables. HDBaseT can power remote TVs and other devices up to 100 watts. A 60" TV connected via an HDBaseT-enabled Cat5e/6 cable requires no power source.<ref name="HDBaseT Technology: A Better HDMI Extender"/>
===Control signals===
HDBaseT delivers control signals starting from [[Consumer Electronics Control#CEC|CEC]] that operates basic functionality such as power-on, power-off and play/stop, to [[RS232]]/USB and IR commands.<ref name="HDBaseT Technology: A Better HDMI Extender"/>
== Variants and application fields ==
=== Audiovisual === Feature attributes of the specification are "5Play feature set, the converged delivery of uncompressed ultra-high-definition digital video and audio, Ethernet, control signals, USB 2.0, and up to 100W of power through a single, 100m/328ft LAN cable."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hdbaset.org/what-is-hdbaset/hdbaset-solution-for-audiovisual/|title=HDBaseT Audiovisual – HDBaseT™|website=hdbaset.org}}</ref>
=== Automotive === Key parameters of the specification are "6Gbs tunneling of video & data, with native networking capabilities over 15m (50ft) of a single [[Twisted_pair#Unshielded_twisted_pair|unshielded twisted-pair (UTP) cable]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hdbaset.org/what-is-hdbaset/hdbaset-solution-for-automotive/|title=HDBaseT Automotive – HDBaseT™|website=hdbaset.org}}</ref>
=== Consumer === This variant of the specification "can distribute audio, video, Ethernet, controls, USB and power over one category cable for 100m/328ft."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hdbaset.org/what-is-hdbaset/hdbaset-solution-for-consumer/|title=HDBaseT Consumer – HDBaseT™|website=hdbaset.org}}</ref> Depictions do suggest usage in a system with a central media cabinet and a distribution hub. Applications could be home entertainment and media delivery as a hotel service.
=== Industrial === This setup claims to make "use of a single category cable to meet all of industrial PC requirements, offering video & audio, Ethernet, controls, USB 2.0 and power over 100m/328ft."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hdbaset.org/what-is-hdbaset/hdbaset-solution-for-industrial/|title=HDBaseT Industrial – HDBaseT™|website=hdbaset.org}}</ref> Further descriptions and depictions indicate the ability of [[Network_topology#Daisy_chain|daisy-chaining]], usage of [[Optical fiber|fiber optics]] for length extending, bi-directional tunneled USB connections and [[KVM switch|KVM-switch]] (keyboard/video/mouse) functionality that is for example usable for various types of terminal applications.
== See also == * [[Audio Video Bridging]] – specifications for synced, low latency streaming through IEEE 802 networks * [[Digital Interface for Video and Audio]] (DiiVA) – bi-directional audio/video at 13.5 Gbit/s over Cat6A * [[DisplayPort]] – audio/video interface at 17.28 Gbit/s * [[UPAMD]] – power supply standards for 10–130 W (optionally 240 W)
==References== {{reflist|2}}
